title-group.article-title: Green's function and forced vibration response of damped axially moving wire

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Stony Brook University, Stony Brook, NY, USA

author-notes.corresp: Chunhui Chung, Department of Mechanical Engineering, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Taipei, Taiwan Email: chunhui.chung@mail.ntust.edu.tw

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, we present a converted closed-form analytical solution for both free and forced vibration responses of a damped axially moving wire, as well as the boundary value problems, based on the Green's function. The Green's function of a damped axially moving wire is derived through an inverse Laplace transform. The corresponding frequency responses when subject to harmonic point excitation are also presented with simulation results. The results show agreement with the results of previous research on free vibration response and corresponding eigensolutions.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Axially moving continua have been utilized in many mechanisms or machines such as belts, chains, and saws. During such operations, the surrounding media may give resistance which would reduce the oscillation. This resistance may be negligible in some cases. However, for manufacturing processes such as a moving wire in a slurry wiresaw system (Kao, 2004; Chung and Kao, 2008; Chung and Kao, 2011), or a cable in water, the damping due to highly viscous fluid has to be considered. In addition to the resistance from surroundings, Li et al. (2003) studied the viscoelastic axially moving belt, where the damping effect comes from the viscoelastic belt, and the system is nonlinear. In this study, a linear system was obtained by neglecting the nonlinear terms in the original nonlinear system; a comparison between nonlinear and linear models was also given. Similar studies of nonlinear viscoelastic moving belts were presented by Zhang and Zu (1998a; 1998b). Garziera and Amabili (2000) studied the boundary value problem of axially moving tapes, where the damping effect comes from the setting of the boundary conditions. Modal analysis was applied to obtain the eigensolutions, and a numerical method was utilized to discuss the response. More complicated systems of axially moving continua may include elastic foundations (Perkins, 1990; Wickert, 1994) and attached oscillators (Lu et al., 2010). A recent thorough review of research on axially moving continua was provided by Chen (2005).

The vibration responses of an undamped axially moving wire and beam with fixed boundaries have been obtained, by utilizing the canonical form and modal analysis, by Wickert and Mote (1990). Van Horssen and Ponomareva (2003; 2005) solved the boundary value problem and vibration response of an axially moving wire via the Laplace transform. These two papers, however, did not extend the study into the damped system, nor the Green's function. The model of a damped axially moving wire in the fluid–string coupled system was first proposed by Huang and Mote (1995). In order to study the slurry wiresaw system (Kao, 2004), Wei and Kao (2000) investigated the harmonic response of the damped model with a numerical method. The free vibration response of the damped axially moving wire was obtained, with its eigensolution and orthogonality, by Chung and Kao (2011). Nevertheless, because of the damping effect, the equation of motion of a damped axially moving wire cannot be converted into the canonical form (with one symmetric and one skew-symmetric matrix differential operators) as those in the undamped systems, and the orthogonality cannot be utilized to decouple the system. Thus, the classical modal analysis is not adequate for the purpose of solving the forced vibration response. Recently, Ma and his colleagues presented the decoupling of the damped linear system (Ma et al., 2009, 2010). However, their research focused on the lumped system, and did not extend to the distributed one.

Green's function is the impulse response of a system. It contains not only the response as a function of time, but also describes the relative motion within the system (Roach, 1982; Butkovskiy, 1983; Duffy, 2001). In addition, its Laplace transform, which is known as the transfer function by the terminology of Butkovskiy (1983), is a powerful tool for the analysis of the system spectrum and response. With the standard form of the system equations, the initial and boundary value problems are also solvable. Yang and Tan (1992) proposed a transform method by casting the system equations into a matrix form in the Laplace domain to obtain the transfer function. Later, Tan and Ying applied the method with a wave propagation function to obtain the solution of an axially moving string with general boundary conditions (Tan and Ying, 1997). Furthermore, the transfer function is feasible for the active vibration control of distributed systems without truncation (Yang and Mote, 1991a,b).

Establishing the transfer functions, as well as the Green's functions, of various distributed systems has various advantages (Butkovskiy, 1983; Butkovskiy and Pustyl'nikov, 1993). However, the Green's function of the damped axially moving wire remains exclusive. In this paper, we present the derivation of the Green's function of a damped axially moving wire. To the best of our knowledge, this paper is the first to derive and present the Green's function as an analytical and closed-form solution for a damped axially moving wire. This new result enables us to obtain the forced vibration response of an axially moving wire in a damped environment, such as that in a modern slurry wiresaw (Kao, 2004).

The Green's function of a damped axially moving wire will be derived in Section 2, followed by the standard form of the equations in Section 3. The standard form of the equations can be utilized to solve the initial and boundary value problems. The frequency response with point excitation is presented in Section 4. The conclusions are in Section 5.

sec.title: 2. Derivation of the Green's function
sec.p: The equation of motion of a damped axially moving wire was proposed by Huang and Mote (1995). Its nondimensionalized form is as follows. (1)utt+2vuxt-(1-v2)uxx+ηvux+ηut=f, where u = u(x, t) is the transverse displacement, v is the constant speed of axial movement, η is the damping factor, x is the spatial coordinate, t is the temporal coordinate, and f is the external force. The boundary conditions are u(x, t) = 0 at x = 0 and x = 1. Assume that the Green's function for the differential equation (1) is g(x, ξ, t, τ), which satisfies the following equation (Butkovskiy, 1983; Stakgold, 1998): (2)gtt+2vgxt-(1-v2)gxx+ηvgx+ηgt=δ(x-ξ)δ(t-τ), where δ(x − ξ) is a Dirac delta function, which postulates that the external force is applied to an arbitrary position ξ within the range of x. Another Dirac delta function δ(t − τ) represents an impulse applied at the time t = τ. The boundary conditions are g(x, ξ, t, τ) = 0 at x = 0 and x = 1. Since this system is stationary linear, which means that this system depends on the difference (t − τ), the Green's function can be represented in the form g(x, ξ, t, τ) = g(x, ξ, t − τ) (Butkovskiy, 1983). The Laplace transform of the Green's function with respect to (t − τ) is G(x,ξ,s)=L{g(x,ξ,t-τ)}=∫0 ∞g(x,ξ,t-τ)e-s(t-τ)d(t-τ), with the boundary conditions G(x, ξ, s) = 0 at x = 0 and x = 1. Take the Laplace transform of the equation of motion (2) to obtain s2G+2vs∂G∂x-(1-v2)∂2G∂x2+ηv∂G∂x+sηG=δ(x-ξ), where G = G(x, ξ, s). The equation can be written as (3)∂2G∂x2-v(2s+η)1-v2∂G∂x-s2+sη1-v2G=-δ(x-ξ)1-v2. When x ≠ ξ, δ(x − ξ) = 0 and the right hand-side of the equation should be zero; that is, (4)∂2G∂x2-v(2s+η)1-v2∂G∂x-s2+sη1-v2G=0, for {0<x<ξξ<x<1 Assuming G(x, ξ, s) = eκx, and substituting it into Equation (4), we can obtain κ as a function of s as follows: (5)κ(s)=α(s)±β(s), where (6)α(s)=v(2s+η)2(1-v2) and β(s)=4s2+4sη+v2η22(1-v2). Therefore, G-(x,ξ,s)=eαx(A(ξ,s)eβx+B(ξ,s)e-βx)for0<x<ξG+(x,ξ,s)=eαx(C(ξ,s)eβx+D(ξ,s)e-βx) forξ<x<1 where A(ξ, s), B(ξ, s), C(ξ, s), and D(ξ, s) are functions to be determined. To satisfy the boundary conditions, G(x, ξ, s) = 0 at x = 0 and x = 1, the functions have the following relationship: B(ξ,s)=-A(ξ,s) and D(ξ,s)=-C(ξ,s)e2β. G-(x,ξ,s)=A(ξ,s)eαx(eβx-e-βx) Hence, we have The function G(x, ξ, s) is continuous at x = ξ, and G−(x, ξ, s) = G+(x, ξ, s). If G(x, ξ, s) is not continuous, then G−(x, ξ, s) ≠ G+(x, ξ, s) at x = ξ, and it means that the wire is broken at the point (Duffy, 2001). Therefore, (7)A(ξ,s)eαξ(eβξ-e-βξ)=C(ξ,s)eαξ(eβξ-e2βe-βξ). Integrate Equation (3) with respect to x, and assume that the integral range is very small around ξ, to obtain (8) ∂G∂x|ξ- ξ+=-11-v2. Substitute G− and G+ into Equation (8) to obtain: (9)C(ξ,s)αeαξ(eβξ-e2βe-βξ)+C(ξ,s)βeαξ(eβξ+e2βe-βξ) -A(ξ,s)αeαξ(eβξ-e-βξ) -A(ξ,s)βeαξ(eβξ+e-βξ)=-11-v2. According to Equations (7) and (9), the functions A(ξ, s) and C(ξ, s) can be solved as A(ξ,s)=11-v2eβξ-e2βe-βξ2βeαξ(1-e2β),C(ξ,s)=11-v2eβξ-e-βξ2βeαξ(1-e2β). We can now obtain the Laplace transform of the Green's function, also known as the transfer function (Butkovskiy, 1983), as follows G(x,ξ,s)={11-v2eβξ-e2βe-βξ2βeαξ(1-e2β)eαx(eβx-e-βx), for 0<x<ξ11-v2eβξ-e-βξ2βeαξ(1-e2β)eαx(eβx-e2βe-βx), for ξ<x<1 which can be rearranged and written as (10)G(x,ξ,s)={11-v2eα(x-ξ)sinhβ(1-ξ)sinhβxβsinhβ, for 0<x<ξ11-v2eα(x-ξ)sinhβ(1-x)sinhβξβsinhβ, for ξ<x<1 The solution of the inverse Laplace transform is (11)g(x,ξ,t-τ)=L-1{G(x,ξ,s)}=12πi∫γ-i∞ γ+i∞G(x,ξ,s)es(t-τ)ds. Since sinh β = 0 at β = ±inπ, the equation Ges(t−τ) has simple poles at (12)sn=-η±i[4n2π2(1-v2)-η2](1-v2)2=-η2±iωn,n=1,2,3,…, and ωn=[4n2π2(1-v2)-η2](1-v2)2. These simple poles are the exact eigenvalues (Chung and Kao, 2011). Note that when β → 0 and s→-η±η1-v22, the limit of G(x, ξ, s)es(t−τ) exist. Therefore, β = 0 is not a pole for G(x, ξ, s)es(t−τ), neither is it for G(x, ξ, s) (Yang and Mote, 1991b). Applying the Residue Theorem to solve Equation (11) (Mathews and Howell, 2006), (13)12πi∫γ-i∞ γ+i∞G(x,ξ,s)es(t-τ)ds=Res[G(x,ξ,s)es(t-τ), s=-η2±iωn]. The Green's function can be obtained by solving Equation (13): (14)g(x,ξ,t-τ)=∑n=1 ∞ [(1-v2)e(-η2+iωn)(t-τ)eαn(x-ξ)sinnπξsinnπxiωn -(1-v2)e(-η2-iωn)(t-τ)e-αn(x-ξ)sinnπξsinnπxiωn ]H(t-τ)=∑n=1 ∞2(1-v2)e-η2(t-τ)ωn [cos (ωn(t-τ) )sin (vωn1-v2(x-ξ) ) +sin (ωn(t-τ) )cos (vωn1-v2(x-ξ) ) ]sinnπxsinnπξH(t-τ), where αn=ivωn1-v2, and H(t − τ) is the Heaviside function. In the solution of the Green's function in Equation (14), the functions of x are the eigenfunctions, and the functions of ξ are the adjoint eigenfunctions.

The forced vibration response can now be obtained by the convolution integral of the Green's function, g(x, ξ, t − τ), in Equation (14) and the external force, f(x, t), as follows (Roach, 1982; Butkovskiy, 1983): (15)u(x,t)=∫0 t∫0 1g(x,ξ,t-τ)f(ξ,τ)dξdτ.

sec.title: 3. The standard form of equations
sec.p: The differential equation (1) requires initial and boundary conditions to render a solution. However, nonhomogeneous initial and boundary conditions often complicate the process of solving such problems. The standard form of equations converts the nonhomogeneous initial and boundary conditions into homogeneous ones, with the original initial and boundary conditions replaced by extra terms in the right-hand side of the equation of motion. Therefore, the Green's function obtained from the homogeneous initial and boundary conditions remains valid for the nonhomogeneous conditions (Butkovskiy, 1983).

Suppose that a stationary linear differential equation is given as (16)L(x,u)=a0u(n)+a1u(n-1)+…+anu=f(x,t) with the initial conditions (17)u(x,t0)=u0(x),∂u∂t(x,t0)=u1(x),…,∂n-1u∂n-1t(x,t0)=un-1(x) and boundary conditions (18)Γi(u)=gi, i=1,2,… Equations (16), (17), and (18) are a system of equations. This system can be converted into the standard form (Butkovskiy, 1983) (19)L(x,u)=a0u(n)+a1u(n-1)+…+anu=f(x,t)+fI(x,t)+fB(x,t) with homogeneous initial conditions (20)u(x,t0)=0,∂u∂t(x,t0)=0,…,∂n-1u∂n-1t(x,t0)=0 and homogeneous boundary conditions (21)Γi(u)=0, i=1,2,… Equations (19), (20), and (21) are called a system of equations in standard form for a given problem. The nonhomogeneous initial and boundary conditions are carried into fI(x, t) and fB(x, t), respectively. The standardizing function actually consists of two components: (i) the standardizing function with respect to the initial conditions, fI(x, t); and (ii) the standardizing function with respect to the boundary conditions, fB(x, t).

The Green's function, g(x, ξ, t − τ), for such a system can be obtained by replacing the forcing functions of the right-hand side of the differential equation (19), f(x, t) + fI(x, t) + fB(x, t), by an impulse input, δ(x − ξ)δ(t − τ). The solution of u(x, t) will be (Butkovskiy, 1983) (22)u(x,t)=∫t0 t∫Dg(x,ξ,t-τ)[f(ξ,τ)+fI(ξ,τ) +fB(ξ,τ)]dξdτ, where D is the domain of x and ξ.

sec.title: 3.1. An example with initial conditions
sec.p: Recall the equation of motion of the damped axially moving wire in Equation (1) utt+2vuxt-(1-v2)uxx+ηvux+ηut=f, with the following initial conditions: (23)u(x,0)=a(x)=0.01sinπx, and ut(x,0)=0 and fixed boundary conditions: (24)Γ1(u)=u(0,t)=0, and Γ2(u)=u(1,t)=0. Since the boundary conditions are homogeneous, i.e. fB(x, t) = 0, only initial conditions have to be standardized. Applying the Laplace transform to Equation (1) with respect to t by incorporating the initial conditions, we obtain s2u¯(x,s)-su(x,0)-ut(x,0)+2v(su¯x(x,s)-ux(x,0)) -(1-v2)u¯xx(x,s)+ηvu¯x(x,s)+η(su¯(x,s) -u(x,0))=f¯(x,s), where ū(x, s) is the Laplace transform of u(x, t), and f¯(x,s) is the Laplace transform of f(x, t). Moving the terms involving the initial conditions to the right-hand side of the equation, we have s2u¯(x,s)+2vsu¯x(x,s)-(1-v2)u¯xx(x,s)+ηvu¯x(x,s) +ηsu¯(x,s)=f¯(x,s)+su(x,0)+ut(x,0)+2vux(x,0) +ηu(x,0). Therefore, the Laplace transform of fI(x, t) is f¯I(x,s)=su(x,0)+ut(x,0)+2vux(x,0)+ηu(x,0). The standardizing function fI(x, t) can be obtained by taking the inverse Laplace transform of f¯I(x,s), which is (25)fI(x,t)=δt(t)u(x,0)+δ(t)[ut(x,0)+2vux(x,0)+ηu(x,0)], where δt(t) is the temporal derivative of δ(t). Substituting the standardizing function into Equation (22) with the corresponding initial conditions given in Equation (23), and zero external force, f(x, t) = 0, the free vibration response of a damped axially moving wire can be obtained in the following: (26)u(x,t)=∫0 t∫0 1g(x,ξ,t-τ)fI(ξ,τ)dξdτ=0.01∫0 t∫0 1g(x,ξ,t-τ)[δτ(τ)sinπξ+δ(τ) ×(2vπcosπξ+ηsinπξ)]dξdτ=-0.01∫0 1gτ(x,ξ,t-0)sinπξdξ +0.01∫0 1g(x,ξ,t-0)(2vπcosπξ+ηsinπξ)dξ=∑n=1 ∞0.02nπ2(1-v2)e-η2tωnNnDn, where the Green's function, g(x, ξ, t − τ), is presented in Equation (14), and Nn= [ (γnη+ (γnηcos(γn)+2 (π2v-π2n2v+vγn 2+γnωn ) ×sin(γn) )cos(nπ) )cos(γnx+ωnt) - (2 (π2v-π2n2v+vγn 2+γnωn ) + (2 (π2v-π2n2v+vγn 2+γnωn )cos(γn) -γnηsin(γn) )cos(nπ) )sin(γnx+ωnt) ]sin(nπx),Dn=π4-2n2π4+n4π4-2π2γn 2-2n2π2γn 2+γn 4. The symbol representation gives rise to γn=vωn1-v2, and ωn is the resonant frequency which is defined as ωn=[4n2π2(1-v2)-η2](1-v2)2.

Given η = 1 and v = 0.3, the plots of the free vibration response in Equation (26) are illustrated in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Plots of the free vibration response of a damped moving wire with nondimensionalized parameters η = 1 and v = 0.3. The initial displacement is u(x, 0) = 0.01 sin πx, and the initial velocity is zero. The boundary conditions are fixed.

sec.title: 3.2. Boundary value problem
sec.p: Recall the equation of motion of the damped axially moving wire in Equation (1), utt+2vuxt-(1-v2)uxx+ηvux+ηut=f. The initial conditions are homogeneous, and the boundary conditions are given in a general form: Γ1(u)=u(0,t),Γ2(u)=u(1,t). Take the Laplace transform with respect to t to obtain s2u¯+2vs∂u¯∂x-(1-v2)∂2u¯∂x2+ηv∂u¯∂x+ηsu¯ =D[u¯(x,s)]=f¯(x,s), with the following boundary conditions: Γ1(u¯)=u¯(0,s),Γ2(u¯)=u¯(1,s), where &#x1D;49F; is the differential operator. Its adjoint differential operator is &#x1D;49F;*, and &#x1D;49F;* ≠ &#x1D;49F; because &#x1D;49F; is non-self-adjoint. The system adjoint equation is D*[w¯(x,s)]=s2w¯-2vs∂w¯∂x-(1-v2)∂2w¯∂x2-ηv∂w¯∂x+ηsw¯=q¯(x,s), with adjoint boundary conditions: Γ1 *(w¯)=w¯(0,s)=0,Γ2 *(w¯)=w¯(1,s)=0. Because D[u¯]=0andD *[G *]=δ(x-ξ), we can obtain ∫0 1D[u¯]w¯dx=∫0 1D*[w¯]u¯dx + [(2vs+ηv)u¯w¯+(1-v2)u¯∂w¯∂x-(1-v2)w¯∂u¯∂x]|0 1, which can be arranged as (27)∫0 1D[u¯]w¯dx-∫0 1D*[w¯]u¯dx =u¯(0,s)[-(2vs+ηv)w¯(0,s)-(1-v2)∂w¯(0,s)∂x] +u¯(1,s)[(2vs+ηv)w¯(1,s)+(1-v2)∂w¯(1,s)∂x] +w¯(0,s)[(1-v2)∂u¯(0,s)∂x] +w¯(1,s)[-(1-v2)∂u¯(1,s)∂x] =Γ1Γ4 *+Γ2Γ3 *+Γ3Γ2 *+Γ4Γ1 *.(27) Assume Γ3=(1-v2)u¯(0,s)∂x and Γ4=-(1-v2)∂u¯(L,s)∂x. The unknown adjoint boundary conditions are Γ3 * and Γ4 *, which can be obtained as Γ3 *(w¯)=(2vs+ηv)w¯(1,s)+(1-v2)∂w¯(1,s)∂x,Γ4 *(w¯)=-(2vs+ηv)w¯(0,s)-(1-v2)∂w¯(0,s)∂x. Because w¯(0,s)=0 and w¯(1,s)=0, Equation (27) becomes (28)∫0 1D[u¯]w¯dx-∫0 1D*[w¯]u¯dx=-(1-v2)u¯(0,s)∂w¯(0,s)∂x +(1-v2)u¯(1,s)∂w¯(1,s)∂x.

Let us assume the original equation of motion is homogeneous, with no external force: D[u¯]=0. In addition, G*(x, ξ, s) is the adjoint Green's function and w¯(x,s)=G*(x,ξ,s). Therefore, D*[G*(x,ξ,s)]=δ(x-ξ). Substitute into Equation (28) to obtain ∫0 LD[u¯]G*dx-∫0 LD*[G*]u¯dx =(1-v2)[-u¯(0,s)∂G*(0,ξ,s)∂x+u¯(1,s)∂G(1,ξ,s)∂x] 0-∫0 Lδ(x-ξ)u¯(x,s)dx=(1-v2)[-u¯(0,s)∂G*(0,ξ,s)∂x+u¯(1,s)∂G(1,ξ,s)∂x], which can be simplified to -u¯(ξ,s)=(1-v2)∫0 1G*(x,ξ,s) [u¯(1,s)δ'(1-x) +u¯(0,s)δ'(x) ]dx=(1-v2)∫0 1G*(y,ξ,s) [u¯(1,s)δ'(1-y) +u¯(0,s)δ'(y) ]dy. Therefore, u¯(x,s)=-(1-v2)∫0 1G*(y,x,s)[u¯(1,s)δ'(1-y) +u¯(0,s)δ'(y)]dy. Because G(x, ξ, s) = G*(ξ, x, s) with homogeneous boundary conditions (Butkovskiy, 1983), the equation above can be written as (29)u¯(x,s)=-(1-v2)∫0 1G(x,y,s)[u¯(1,s)δ'(1-y) +u¯(0,s)δ'(y)]dy=-(1-v2)∫0 1G(x,ξ,s)[u¯(1,s)δ'(1-ξ) +u¯(0,s)δ'(ξ)]dξ.

statement.title: Example
statement.p:
Given a system of damped axially moving wire with homogeneous initial conditions and nonhomogeneous boundary conditions, Γ1(u) = u(0, t) = sin Ωt, Γ2(u) = u(1, t) = 0. The response in the s-domain can be obtained by Equation (29). Take the Laplace transform on the boundary conditions to obtain Γ1(u¯)=u¯(0,s)=Ωs2+Ω2,Γ2(u¯)=u¯(1,s)=0, and substitute into Equation (29): (30)u¯(x,s)=-(1-v2)∫0 1G(x,ξ,s)[u¯(0,s)δ'(ξ)]dξ=(1-v2)Ωs2+Ω2dGdξ|ξ=0. Because ξ = 0 < x, the corresponding Green's function in Equation (10) is G(x,ξ,s)=11-v2eα(x-ξ)sinhβ(1-x)sinhβξβsinhβ, where α(s)=v(2s+η)2(1-v2), and β(s)=4s2+4sη+v2η22(1-v2). Therefore, dGdξ|ξ=0=11-v2 [-αeα (x-ξ )sinhβ (1-x )sinhβξβsinhβ +eα (x-ξ )βsinhβ (1-x )coshβξβsinhβ ]|ξ=0=11-v2 [eαxsinhβ (1-x )sinhβ ]. Substituting into Equation (30), we have (31)u¯(x,s)=Ωs2+Ω2eαxsinhβ(1-x)sinhβ. The simple singularities are at s = iΩ and s = −iΩ, at which βiΩ=-4Ω2+4iΩη+v2η22(1-v2) and β-iΩ=-4Ω2-4iΩη+v2η22(1-v2). The other simple singularities are β±n = ±inπ, at which s±n=-η±i[4n2π2(1-v2)-η2](1-v2)2=-η2±iωn. Apply the Residue Theorem for the inverse Laplace transform to obtain: (32)u(x,t)=ev(η+2iΩ)2(1-v2)xsinhβiΩ(1-x)2isinhβiΩeiΩt -ev(η-2iΩ)2(1-v2)xsinhβ-iΩ(1-x)2isinhβ-iΩe-iΩt +∑n=1 ∞Ω(1-v2)2nπeivωn1-v2xsinnπxiωn(η24-iωnη-ωn 2+Ωn 2)e(-η2+iωn)t -∑n=1 ∞Ω(1-v2)2nπe-ivωn1-v2xsinnπxiωn(η24+iωnη-ωn 2+Ω2)e(-η2-iωn)t. The responses are plotted in Figure 2, based on the prescribed process parameters. Equation (31) can also be obtained by taking the Laplace transform of the equation of motion and the boundary conditions, and then solving the transferred ordinary differential equation (van Horssen, 2003). However, the advantages of the standard form would be eliminated. Figure 2.
Plots of the vibration response of a damped moving wire with the boundary conditions in Equation (32). The nondimensionalized η = 1 and v = 0.3. The boundary conditions are u(0, t) = sin Ωt and u(1, t) = 0, where Ω = 5.236.

sec.title: 4. Frequency response with point excitation
sec.p: The frequency response with point excitation of a damped axially moving wire has been studied using numerical analysis in (Chung and Kao, 2009). The closed-form solution of the Green's function derived in Equation (14) can be employed to obtain the frequency response analytically. In the following subsections, we present two methods for obtaining the frequency response subject to a point harmonic excitation of f(x, t) = δ(x − a)eiωt. We also compare the results obtained by the two independent methods; namely, by the Green's function and by the flexibility influence function.

sec.title: 4.1. Frequency response by the Green's function
sec.p: Frequency response is very important in the analysis of vibration. It renders the spectrum of responses in the frequency domain and amplitudes of vibration response near the locations of the resonant frequencies of a system. Frequency response and the spectral density are fundamental in the study of control theory and random vibration analysis.
The Green's function was derived in Section 2, and the vibration response can be obtained by the integral equation (15) as follows: u(x,t)=∫0 t∫0 1g(x,ξ,t-τ)f(ξ,τ)dξdτ.

In order to obtained the frequency response with point excitation, we assume a point harmonic excitation, f(x, t) = δ(x − a)eiωt, where a is the position to which external excitation is applied, as shown in Figure 3. The vibration response is (33)u(x,t)=∫0 t∫0 1g(x,ξ,t-τ)δ(ξ-a)eiωτdξdτ=∑n=1 ∞1-v2iωn[eαn(x-a)sinnπasinnπxη2+i(ω-ωn) -e-αn(x-a)sinnπasinnπxη2+i(ω+ωn)]eiωt -∑n=1 ∞1-v2iωneαn(x-a)sinnπasinnπxη2+i(ω-ωn)e(-η2+iωn)t +∑n=1 ∞1-v2iωne-αn(x-a)sinnπasinnπxη2+i(ω+ωn)e(-η2-iωn)t. The transient response of the last two terms of summations decays with time and approaches zero as time progresses. The decaying envelope is e-η2t. The first summation term is the steady-state response, whose coefficient is (34)Z(x,a,ω)=∑n=1 ∞1-v2iωn[eαn(x-a)sinnπasinnπxη2+i(ω-ωn) -e-αn(x-a)sinnπasinnπxη2+i(ω+ωn)], which is considered as the frequency response with point excitation. Figure 4(a) shows an example of the absolute value (magnitude of the frequency response) of Equation (34) with respect to the excitation frequency ω. Figure 3.
Schematic of wiresaw with point excitation, f(a, t), applied at x = a. The wire is moving with a speed of v. Figure 4.
Magnitude of the frequency response at x = 0.25 with point excitation at a = 0.5 and nondimensionalized velocity v = 0.3. The magnitude of the frequency response is obtained from (a) Equation (34) by the Green's function; and (b) Equation (40) by the flexibility influence function. Both analytical methods independently produce results which are identical to each other.

sec.title: 4.2. Frequency response by the flexibility influence function
sec.p: Another method for determining the frequency response is the flexibility influence function (Newland, 2005). To obtain the frequency response, we assume the response is u(x, t) = Z(x, a, ω)eiωt, subject to f = eiωt δ(x − a), where Z(X, a, ω) is the frequency response of the axially moving wire, a is the point of excitation, and ω is the frequency of the external excitation. Substitute these terms into Equation (1) to obtain: (35)(1-v2)d2Zdx2-(ηv+2ivω)dZdx+(ω2-iωη)Z=-δ(x-a). The impulse function, δ(x − a), of the equation is zero except at x = a. Thus, we have (1-v2)d2Z-dx2-(ηv+2ivω)dZ-dx+(ω2-iωη)Z-=0 for 0<x<a(1-v2)d2Z+dx2-(ηv+2ivω)dZ+dx+(ω2-iωη)Z+=0 for a<x<1 Next, we assume Z(x, a, ω) = eλ(ω)x. Thus, the solutions of λ are the roots of (1-v2)λ2-(2ivω+ηv)λ+(ω2-iωη)=0. Therefore, (36)λ=2ivω+ηv±η2v2-4ω2+4iωη2(1-v2)=α±β. The frequency response is obtained in the following: Z-(x,a,ω)=eαx(Aeβx+Be-βx) for0<x<aZ+(x,a,ω)=eαx(Ceβx+De-βx) fora<x<1 Apply the boundary conditions, Z−(0, a, ω) = Z+(1, a, ω) = 0, to obtain B = −A and D = −Ce2β. Thus, we have Z-(x,a,ω)=Aeαx(eβx-e-βx) for0<x<aZ+(x,a,ω)=Ceαx(eβx-e2βe-βx) fora<x<1

Since the string is continuous at x = a, we require Z−(x, a, ω) = Z+(x, a, ω) at x = a. Consequently, (37)Aeαa(eβa-e-βa)=Ceαa(eβa-e2βe-βa). In addition, the force equilibrium at x = a renders (38)(1-v2)(dZ +(x,a,ω)dx-dZ -(x,a,ω)dx)=-1. Therefore, (39)C [αeαa (eβa-e2βe-βa )+βeαa (eβa+e2βe-βa ) ]-A [αeαa (eβa-e-βa )+βeαa (eβa+e-βa ) ]=-11-v2. The coefficients, A and C, can be obtained by solving Equations (37) and (39) as follows: A=eβa-e2βe-βa2(1-v2)β(1-e2β)eαa,C=eβa-e-βa2(1-v2)β(1-e2β)eαa. Therefore, the frequency response of the damped axially moving wire is Z(x,a,ω)={eβa-e2βe-βa2(1-v2)β(1-e2β)eα(x-a)(eβx-e-βx), for 0<x<aeβa-e-βa2(1-v2)β(1-e2β)eα(x-a)(eβx-e2βe-βx), for a<x<1 By representing the equation of Z(x, a, ω) using the sinh functions, the frequency response can be simplified as (40)Z(x,a,ω)={eα(x-a)sinh(1-a)sinhx(1-v2)βsinhβ, for 0<x<aeα(x-a)sinhasinh(1-x)(1-v2)βsinhβ, for a<x<1

Equation (40) is applied in an example with x = 0.25 with a point excitation at a = 0.5 and velocity v = 0.3. The results are plotted in Figure 4(b) with the prescribed parameters, and compared with the solution obtained by the Green's function in Equation (34). The plots show consistent results for the frequency response between the two independent methods.

sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: The Green's function for a damped axially moving wire is derived and presented in this paper. The results show that the poles of the Green's function in the s-domain of the Laplace transform are actually the eigenvalues, and the Green's function is a combination of the eigenfunctions and adjoint eigenfunctions. Based on the Green's function obtained in this paper, we present the closed-form solution of the forced vibration response of a damped axially moving wire, as well as the free vibration response, boundary value problem, and frequency response with a point harmonic excitation. By utilizing the standard form, the response with nonhomogeneous initial and boundary conditions can be solved by the Green's function with homogeneous conditions. In addition, the results of frequency response with point excitation solved by the Green's function are compared with the results based on the flexibility influence function. The results obtained from both methods are shown to be consistent with each other. The analytical solution of the Green's function presented in this paper forms a foundation of control theory and random vibration analysis for damped axially moving continua.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: None declared.
